com.gnahraf.util.cc.throt

Class FuzzySpeed

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gnahraf.util.cc.throt.FuzzySpeed
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    FuzzySpeedBean

    public abstract class FuzzySpeed
extends Object
    Fuzzy membership set abstraction for speed state. The return value of each member function (method) represents the degree by which the speed is in that state. Valid return values for any method are anything non-negative, although typically normalized return values in the range [0, 1] will be used.

    Think of speed here as some metric that when too high must be throttled. It needn't be time-based; it may be resource-based: for example, the number of threads servicing requests. To implement a method, think of how a human monitoring an analog dial of the metric might interpret the adjective represented by the method name (for example accelerating) and return 0 if inapt, 1 if certainly apt, or any where in between for the gray areas. It really doesn't matter if you only return one of say 3 or 4 values: it works surprisingly well with simple, crude models.

    Author:
    Babak
    See Also:
    snapshot()

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      abstract double accelerating()
      Is the needle rising? Second order property.

      Is the needle holding steady? Second order property.

      Is the needle descending? Second order property.
      abstract double justRight()
      Are we chugging along just fine?
      FuzzySpeed snapshot()
      Returns a fixed snapshot of the instance's state.
      abstract double tooFast()
      Are we going too fast? (Is the needle in the the red zone on the dial?)
      abstract double tooSlow()
      Are we going too slow? (The needle ought to be pointing higher on the dial.)

      • snapshot

        public FuzzySpeed snapshot()
        Returns a fixed snapshot of the instance's state.

        Note this method synchronizes on the instance itself. The goal here is that a subclass only ever mutate an instance's state while holding the instance's monitor. That way, this method can truly guarantee a snapshot of the speed state.
